ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Thinking more skeptically about technology and politics, especially their intersection
I learned a lot about how governments, societies, and companies interact in the modern age, as well as the implications that exist at the intersection of tech and policy going forward.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Reading can be a bit tedious, but Professor Hersh does a good job summarizing it in class. he also focusses on writing style and presentation techniques more than other professors which is good.

The course was very well organized and had clearly defined topics for each week's discussion. The only thing I would say is that some of the weeks had unrealistic reading assignments--I don't think many students would have the time to read several 30-page papers on top of a book in one week.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Good class with interesting topics, I really like Professor Hersh.

I would definitely recommend this course, except Professor Hersh is leaving! I loved taking it with him because his area of research was this specific field, and he had a lot of interesting anecdotes and insight that helped supplement the class greatly.

Yes, I would recommend this class (if it's still around). The readings are great but plentiful on average. Prof. Hersh is engaging and has done some wonderful work. Discussion is usually thought-provoking. There are interesting guest lecturers (one from industry and one from the more legal side of things). Prof. Hersh isn't worried about sharing his opinions but will also listen to yours. Three 5 page papers, a weekly paragraph-long reading response (useful if you're not big on speaking in seminars), and an in-class presentation. The papers are tougher than you think. Each is unique and Prof. Hersh has a very specific set of stipulations for you (stipulations that he only explains verbally). You'll need to adjust to his style of writing (he doesn't like adjectives, quotes, etc.). He also grades anonymously and quickly. You'll get very thorough feedback and learn what is expected of you fast.
